current_subquestions: Q1: Identify the cells that are surrounded by the same color on all four sides.
new_subanswers_ys: A1: To identify the cells that are surrounded by the same color on all four sides, we can iterate through each cell in the grid. For each cell, we check its top, bottom, left, and right neighbors. If all four neighbors have the same color as the current cell, we mark this cell as surrounded.
A2: After identifying these cells, we should change the color of the cell to the color of the surrounding cells.

A3: For the cells on the edges of the grid, we can consider them as not being surrounded by the same color on all four sides, since they don't have four neighbors. Therefore, we don't change their color.

A4: For the cells that are surrounded by different colors on different sides, we don't change their color. We only change the color of the cells that are surrounded by the same color on all four sides.

A5: For the cells that are surrounded by the same color on three sides but a different color on one side, we don't change their color. We only change the color of the cells that are surrounded by the same color on all four sides.

A1: To identify the cells that are surrounded by the same color on all four sides, we can iterate through each cell in the grid. For each cell, we check its top, bottom, left, and right neighbors. If all four neighbors have the same color as the current cell, then the current cell is surrounded by the same color on all four sides.
A2: The rule to change the color of the cells is that if a cell is surrounded by the same color on all four sides, then the color of the cell changes to the color of the surrounding cells.

A3: To apply the rule to all cells in the grid, we can iterate through each cell in the grid and check if it is surrounded by the same color on all four sides. If it is, we change the color of the cell to the color of the surrounding cells. We repeat this process until no more cells can be changed.
A4: The output grid for the given input grid can be obtained by applying the rule to all cells in the grid. The output grid is the final state of the grid after no more cells can be changed.

current_subquestions: Q1: Identify the cells that are surrounded by the same color on all four sides.

Q4: Repeat the process for all colors present in the grid.
new_subanswers_ys:

A2: To determine the color of the surrounding cells, we can simply check the color of any one of the neighboring cells that we have confirmed to be the same in the previous step. Since all four neighbors have the same color, checking one is sufficient.
A3: To replace the identified cells with the color of the surrounding cells, we can iterate through the grid again. For each cell that we have marked as surrounded, we change its color to the color of its neighbors that we determined in the previous step.
A4: To repeat the process for all colors present in the grid, we can keep track of all unique colors present in the grid. Then, we can repeat the steps outlined above for each unique color. This can be done by wrapping the entire process in a loop that iterates over each unique color.
